chapter: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following biochemical reactions does not occur in mitochondria?
questions.explanation: Fatty acid synthesis primarily occurs in the cytoplasm.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following pathways utilizes NADPH as the source of reducing equivalent?
questions.explanation: NADPH is the source of reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis. The NADPH utilized for fatty acid synthesis is derived from three sources: the HMP shunt pathway (major source), extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source), and malic enzyme.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following pathway is the most important source of reducing equivalents for fattyacid synthesis in the liver?
questions.explanation: The reducing equivalent for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is NADPH. The most important sourceof NADPH is the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway.The HMP shunt pathway, or pentose phosphate pathway, is an alternative route for themetabolism of glucose. It generates NADPH and synthesizes ribose. NADP+ is hydrogenated toNADPH by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase. Since the HMP shunt pathway and de novo fattyacid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeabilitybarriers against the transfer of NADPH. Thus, this forms the major source for NADPH for fattyacid synthesis.Other minor sources of NADPH are extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase and NADPmalate dehydrogenase (malic enzyme).
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of the fatty acid synthesis pathway?
questions.explanation: Acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the fatty acid synthesis pathway. Acetyl CoA carboxylase converts acetyl CoA into malonyl CoA, the first step of de novo fatty acid synthesis. It is an allosteric enzyme activated by citrate in the well-fed state. Acetyl CoA carboxylase requires the following: NADPH as the reducing equivalent, biotin is a coenzyme needed by carboxylases, ATP for energy, manganese (Mn2+), and HCO3- as the carbon donor. Fatty acid synthesis: CoA, Acetyl CoA, Citrate synthase, COA, Mitochondria, Cytosol, Matrix, 2 Malonyl CoA formation, Oxaloacetate, Citrate, CA, Citrate, 1 shuttle, OAA, COA, COA, Acetyl CoA, Citrate, High energy! ADP, ATP, Biotin, Acetyl CoA carboxylase, HCO3, Long-chain fatty acyl CoA, DP, COA, Malonyl CoA.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following is an allosteric activator of acetyl CoA carboxylase?
questions.explanation: Citrate is an allosteric activator of acetyl-CoA carboxylase. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo fatty acid synthesis. Citrate promotes the conversion of acetyl CoA carboxylase from an inactive dimer to an active polymeric form. Its concentration increases in the well-fed state. Insulin also activates the enzyme by dephosphorylating it. Glucagon and epinephrine promote inactivation of acetyl-CoA carboxylase by phosphorylation of the enzyme. Long-chain acyl-CoA molecules, such as palmitoyl CoA, also promote inactivation of the enzyme. Activation and inactivation of the carboxylase enzyme: AMP-activated protein kinase, ATP, ADP, active carboxylase, inactive carboxylase, protein phosphatase 2, Pi, H2O. Examples of allosteric modifiers: Enzyme - 1. ALA synthase, 2. Aspartate transcarbamoylase, 3. HMG CoA reductase, 4. Phosphofructokinase, 5. Acetyl CoA carboxylase, 6. Citrate synthase, 7. Carbamoyl phosphate synthase-I, 8. Carbamoyl phosphate synthase-II. Allosteric inhibitor - Heme, CTP, Cholesterol. Allosteric activator - Citrate, ATP, Acyl CoA, ATP-AMP, F2,6P, Citrate-NAG, ATP.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which is an important intermediate product of fatty acid biosynthesis?
questions.explanation: Malonyl-CoA is an important intermediate product of fatty acid biosynthesis. Production of malonyl-CoA from acetyl CoA is the initial and rate-limiting step in fatty acid synthesis. Bicarbonate is a source of CO2 and is required in the initial reaction for the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA in the presence of ATP and acetyl-CoA carboxylase. Fatty acid synthesis occurs with citrate synthase, acetyl CoA, CoA, mitochondria, cytosol, matrix, 2 malonyl CoA formation, CoA, acetyl CoA, ATP, biotin, HCO3, and ADP.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: A child with severe acute malnutrition is undergoing nutritional rehabilitation. Duringfollow-up visits, he shows significant improvement in appetite, an adequate gain of weight,and a gradual increase in subcutaneous body fat. Activity of which of the following enzymes isresponsible for the restoration of fat storage in this patient?
questions.explanation: OxaloacetateCitrateCACCitrate1 shuttleOAACOACitrateHigh energy!ADPATPAcetyl CoA carboxylaseCOAMalonyl CoAMARROWLong-chainfatty acyl CoA220The restoration of fat storage in a child undergoing nutritional rehabilitation, as evidenced byadequate weight gain and an increase in subcutaneous body fat, occurs with the help of acetyl CoAcarboxylase.With appropriate supplementation of nutrition, the child's body will gradually enter an anabolicphase. In the well fed state, there is an abundant supply of glucose, which is converted topyruvate, which in turn is converted to acetyl CoA. Acetyl CoA is diverted into fatty acid synthesis,in which acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme. There is also a high insulin : glucagonratio in the well fed state. This favors dephosphorylation (activation) of acetyl CoA carboxylase,resulting in increased fatty acid synthesis. The fatty acids thus formed (most commonly palmitoylCoA) are esterified into triacylglycerols. This process is called lipogenesis.Note: The enzymes acyl-CoA dehydrogenase, thiolase, and carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I areinvolved in fatty acid oxidation and are inactive in the well-fed state.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis pathway?
questions.explanation: The most common end product of fatty acid synthesis is palmitic acid. Palmitic acid is a 16-carbon saturated long-chain fatty acid (LCFA). The substrate for its synthesis is acetyl CoA. Acetyl CoA is also the end product of fatty acid beta-oxidation.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the mechanism of synthesis of fatty acids is correct?

options.A: Acetyl-CoA is the most active donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.
options.B: Malonyl-CoA is the most active donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.
options.C: Fatty acid synthesis is the reverse of oxidation of fatty acids.
options.D: Coenzyme A is the acyl group carrier of intermediates in fatty acid synthesis.

questions.explanation: Malonyl-CoA is the most active donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.Malonyl-CoA is a 3-carbon unit that donates 2 carbon units in fatty acid synthesis. It is formedfrom acetyl-CoA by acetyl-CoA carboxylase. During fatty acid synthesis, acetyl CoA primarily actsas the primer. The enzyme fatty acid synthase (FAS) adds two carbons from malonyl-CoA to theinital acetyl-CoA, forming a 4-carbon intermediate (butyryl-ACP). FAS then sequentially adds twocarbons from malonyl-CoA to the ACP-intermediates (eg: butyryl-ACP) to elongate the fatty acidchain.Thus, in the end product palmitic acid (C16), only carbon atoms 15 and 16 are from acetyl CoA.The remaining 14 carbon atoms are derived from malonyl-CoA. Thus, malonyl-CoA is the mostactive donor of two carbon atoms in fatty acid synthesis.Note:Option 3: Fatty acid synthesis is not a simple reversal of oxidation of fatty acids. These twoprocesses involve completely different enzymes and occur in different compartments of the cell.Option 4: Intermediates in fatty acid synthesis are covalently linked to the sulfhydryl group ofan acyl carrier protein (ACP), not coenzyme A, of the enzyme fatty acid synthase. Intermediates inthe fatty acid breakdown are covalently attached to the sulfhydryl group of coenzyme A.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: In which of the following steps of fatty acid synthesis is CO2 produced?
questions.explanation: 221In fatty acid synthesis, CO2 is produced in the condensation step.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the fatty acid synthase complex?
questions.explanation: Acetyl CoA carboxylase is not a part of the fatty acid synthase complex.The fatty acid synthase complex is a multienzyme polypeptide complex that synthesizes fatty acidsfrom malonyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA. It is a dimer of two identical polypeptide monomers(homodimer). Each monomer contains six enzymes and the acyl carrier protein (ACP). ACPcarries the intermediate products formed during fatty acid synthesis. The enzymes of the fattyacid synthase complex are as follows:1. Condensing unit:•Ketoacyl synthase.Malonyl/acetyl transacylase2. Reduction unit:• Dehydratase• Enoyl reductase•• Beta-ketoacyl reductase3. Releasing unit:•Thioesterase
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: The elongation of long chain fatty acids takes place in which if the following hepatocyteorganelles?
questions.explanation: The elongation of long chain fatty acids takes place in the 1. endoplasmic reticulum and 3.mitochondria of hepatocytes.Fatty acid elongation occurs in three cellular compartments: the cytosol, mitochondria, andendoplasmic reticulum (microsomes). Both unsaturated and saturated fatty acids can beelongated, with malonyl-CoA acting as the 2 carbon donor and NADPH as the reducing agent.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Stearic acid is converted into which of the following fatty acids by the enzyme 9 desaturase?
questions.explanation: Stearic acid is converted to oleic acid by the enzyme 9 desaturase.■9 desaturase is present in the endoplasmic reticulum. It catalyzes the synthesis ofmonounsaturated fatty acids (Eg: Oleic acid) from saturated fatty acids (Eg: Stearic acid).■9 desaturase is a mixed-function oxidase, requiring NADPH and O2. The first double bond isalways introduced in the 9 positions. Humans cannot introduce double bonds beyond ■9positions (between C-10 and terminal methyl group). Hence, linoleic (A9,12) and linolenic acid(A9,12,15) are considered essential fatty acids and should be included in the diet.222
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding the role of insulin on lipid metabolism?

options.B: Increasing the transport of glucose into the cells

questions.explanation: Inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase is not an action of insulin. Insulin activates the pyruvatedehydrogenase enzyme.•Insulin stimulates lipogenesis by the following mechanisms:⚫ Decreasing the level of intracellular cAMP. This favours dephosphorylation of acetyl-CoAcarboxylase, resulting in its activation.• Increasing acetyl-CoA carboxylase activity. This accelerates the rate-limiting step of fatty acidsynthesis.• Increasing the transport of glucose into the cell and activation of pyruvate dehydrogenase in theadipose tissue. This yields more acetyl CoA for fatty acid synthesis.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Eicosanoids are derived from fatty acids with
questions.explanation: Eicosanoids are derived from fatty acids with 20C.Eicosanoids are formed from arachidonic acid and other C20 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA).They are short-acting paracrine chemicals that bring about their action through aG-protein-coupled receptor.Types of eicosanoids:• Prostanoids•Prostaglandins (E & F)• Prostacyclins• Thromboxanes• Leukotrienes•⚫ Lipoxins
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: What is the first step in synthesis of eicosanoids?
questions.explanation: The first step in the synthesis of eicosanoids involves the activation of hydrolase. Eicosanoid synthesis is governed by the rate of release of arachidonic acid from membrane lipids in response to appropriate stimuli (e.g., increased calcium). These stimuli activate hydrolases, including phospholipase A2, which releases arachidonic acid from membrane phospholipids. The released arachidonic acid is then converted into: Prostaglandins and thromboxanes by the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway. PGH2 synthase is the first enzyme of this pathway. Leukotrienes and lipoxins by the lipoxygenase (LOX) pathway. Prostaglandin synthesis: Diacylglycerol or phospholipid, lipoxygenase (FLAP, Alox5), phospholipase C, phospholipase A2, arachidonic acid, PGH2 synthase (cox-1 or -2 and peroxidase), Prostaglandin H2 (PGH2), PGD synthase, PGD2, PGE synthase, PGE2, PGF2, prostacyclin synthase, thromboxane synthase, HPETE (hydroperoxy-eicosatetraenoic acid), H2O, LTB4, Leukotriene A4, glutathione, glutathione-S-transferase, Leukotriene C4, glutamic acid, Leukotriene D4, prostacyclin (PGI2), thromboxane (TXA2), endothelium, platelets, 6-keto-PGF1a, thromboxane (TXA2), marrow, Leukotriene E4.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which substance is least likely to have its production decreased by aspirin?
questions.explanation: Aspirin is least likely to decrease the production of leukotrienes. Aspirin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway. The cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway generates eicosanoids with a ring structure - prostaglandins, thromboxane, prostacyclin. Leukotrienes, however, are produced by the lipoxygenase pathway (LOX), which is not inhibited by aspirin. Steroids, prostaglandin synthesis: cell membrane phospholipids, phospholipase C, phospholipase A2. COX1 and COX2 inhibitors, such as aspirin, indomethacin, inhibit PGH synthase (cyclooxygenase COX 1 and COX2, peroxidase). Other lipoxygenases, such as 5-lipoxygenase (ALOX5), produce HPETE (hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid), which is then converted to leukotriene A4 by 12-lipoxygenase. Lipoxin A4 and lipoxin B4 inhibit inflammation and chemotaxis. Leukotriene A4 will be converted to leukotriene C4 by glutathione-S-transferase, then to leukotriene D4 and leukotriene E4. Prostaglandin H2 (PGH2) is converted to PGE2, PGF2, prostacyclin (PGI2), and thromboxane (TXA2) by their respective synthases. PGE2 causes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability. Prostacyclin (PGI2) causes vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation. Thromboxane (TXA2) causes vasoconstriction and promotes platelet aggregation.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following are unstable intermediate products of the cyclooxygenase pathway?
questions.explanation: PGG2 and PGH2 are unstable intermediates of the cyclooxygenase (COX) pathway. The cyclooxygenase enzyme of the COX pathway is a bifunctional enzyme. It first oxidizes arachidonic acid to PGG2 and then peroxidizes PGG2 to PGH2. These two intermediates (cyclic endoperoxides) are unstable. PGH2 is metabolized further by specific synthases and isomerases into a variety of eicosanoids, including PGE2, PGD2, PGF2α, prostacyclin (PGI2), and thromboxane (TX) A2.
questions.chapter_heading: Biosynthesis of fatty acids and Eicosanoids

questions.question: Which of the following is not a primary prostaglandin?
questions.explanation: PGI2 is not a primary prostaglandin. PGD2, PGE2, and PGF2α are called the primary prostaglandins based on their structure. Primary prostaglandins contain a single cyclopentane ring with a 15-hydroxyl group with a 13,14-trans double bond. Prostacyclin, or PGI2, structurally differs from the primary prostaglandins due to its double ring structure. Prostaglandin synthesis: Diacylglycerol or phospholipid, Phospholipase A2, Phospholipase C, PGH2 synthase (cox-1 or -2 and peroxidase), Prostaglandin H2 (PGH2), PGD synthase, PGE synthase, PGE2, Arachidonic acid, Prostacyclin synthase, Thromboxane synthase, Lipooxygenase (FLAP Alox5), HPETE (hydroperoxy-eicosatetraenoic acid), H2O, LTB4, Leukotriene A4, Glutathione, Glutathione-S-transferase, Leukotriene C4, Glutamic acid, PGD2, PGF2, Prostacyclin (PGI2), Thromboxane (TXA2), Endothelium, Platelets, 6-keto-PGF1a, Thromboxane (TXA2), MARROW, Leukotriene D4, Leukotriene E4.

questions.question: A 7-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe breathlessness with wheezing. Her peakexpiratory flow rate is reduced significantly. Which of the following enzymes is important forthe pathogenesis of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Sudden onset of severe breathlessness and wheezing with a reduced peak expiratory flow rate issuggestive of acute exacerbation of asthma. 5-lipoxygenase enzyme is important for thepathogenesis of this condition.Acute exacerbation of asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction due to chemicals mediatorslike leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4 etc.). Leukotrienes are produced from the breakdown ofarachidonic acid by 5-lipoxygenase via the lipoxygenase pathway.226SteroidsProstaglandins synthesisCell membrane phospholipids.Phospholipase CPhospholipase AgOtherlipooxygenaseArachidonic acidHPETEHETESLipooxygenas(FLAR (10×5)12-lipooxygenaseHPETE (hydroperoxy-eicosatetraenoic acidCOX1 and COX2 inhibitors,aspirin, indomethacin.PGH, synthase(Cyclooxygenase COX1and CO×2, peroxidase )Lipoxin A4.Lipoxin B4Inhibition ofinflammationChemotaxisH.OLeukotriene AGlutathione-S-transferaLeukotriene CLTB.GlutathioneGlutamiencidLeukotriene D.Prostaglandin H, (PGH;)Leukotriene EasynthasePGDPGD.PGE2Gausenvasodilation.increased vascularpermeabilityPGE2PGEPGF2synthaseProstacyclinProstacyclin(PGI)EndotheliumCausesvasodilation,inhibits plateletOMARROWBronchospasm.increasedVascularpermeabilitysynthaseThromboxaneThromboxane(TXA)PlateletsCausesVasoconstriction.promotes plateletaggregationLeukotrienes are eicosanoic acid derivatives formed in leukocytes, mast cells, platelets, andmacrophages. They are potent constrictors of the bronchial airway. Leukotrienes also causeincreased vascular permeability and activation and attraction of leukocytes. Thus, they areinvolved in many inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions, such as asthma.

questions.question: What is the first intermediate product of the LOX pathway?
questions.explanation: Hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid (HPETE) is the first intermediate product produced in the LOXpathway.5-lipoxygenase, the first enzyme of the LOX pathway, breaks down arachidonic acid into5-hydroperoxyeicosatetraenoic acid (5-HPETE) which undergoes further chemical reactions toproduce leukotrienes (LTS), hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid (HETE) and lipoxins.Prostaglandins synthesisDiacylglycerol or phospholipidPhospholipase A2Phospholipase CPGH2 synthase(cox-1 or -2 and peroxidase)Prostaglandin H₂ (PGH2)PGD synthasePGD2PGE synthasePGE2Arachidonic acidProstacyclin synthaseThromboxane synthaseLipooxygenase(FLAP Alox5)HPETE (hydroperoxy-eicosatetraenoic acidH₂OLTB4Leukotriene A4GlutathioneGlutathione-S-transferaseLeukotriene CaGlutamicacidPGF2Prostacyclin Thromboxane(PGI2)(TXA2)EndotheliumPlatelets6-keto-PGF1aThromboxane(TXA2)OMARROW227Leukotriene D4Leukotriene Ea228
